comments.author: justin
comments.content: That looks fantastic. I think you may love mushrooms as much as I do! I love to brush a maitake with garlic butter and pop it in a hot oven to crisp up the edges and serve it on a cheese plate.

comments.author: Kat
comments.content: Microwave? Really? For such a gourmet dish?!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Microwaves are awesome, if used for the right things. They work by vibrating water molecules in your food. So for situations where you want to quickly soften something like the bok choy in this dish, or melt chocolate or butter, they are great. Like any other tool, it is all about how you use it. More discussion in the comments here: https://herbivoracious.com/2010/01/brussels-sprout-gratin-with-heretical-technique-recipe.html

comments.author: Kat
comments.content:
Thank you for the link. I guess it is the matter of personal preference. Nice to know that Paule Bocuse shares my taste in cooking :)
Thank you for inspiring recipes and entertaining stories.

comments.author: Jen
comments.content:
This looks just beautiful! 

Wild mushrooms are almost unheard of at my farmers' market though; I'm thinking slabs of roasted king oyster mushrooms and some rice would make a tasty adaptation (kind of a riff on ochazuke).

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I like the idea of doing it with rice if you can't get the maitake. A bit of a different dish but I think it would be delicious. You could even grill the king oysters to get some char and add more flavor.

comments.author: Rachel Cotterill
comments.content: I've never seen this kind of mushroom before - it looks intriguing!

comments.author: Stephen Kjeldsen
comments.content: I am Danish, and we use celcius. 90 % of the times I read fahrenheit, I read celcius and it is first when I stand in front of the oven I say to myself "450 degrees?! Waaaait second!". It all went fine, and even though it didn't look as good as yours, it tasted great!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Ha, well, it would be *really* well roasted :)!

comments.author: Sally
comments.content:
At last, someone else who appreciates how great a food accompaniment tea is!  I use it all the time to add depth and nuances to dishes, whether green tea or black!  And with mushrooms - divine!  Even Tetsuya, one of Australia's leading chefs, makes a tea broth that has chopped tomatoes warmed in black tea then strained and used as a broth base for fish.

Thanks for the great recipe.
